qas.question: What is a commonly used term for infrared radiation?
What percentage of the Earth's heat is derived from the Sun's infrared light?
What is the common range of emitted radiation of room temperature objects, in micrometers?
Other than infrared light, what type of light is responsible for heating the Earth?
What radiation is responsible for 49% of the heating of the Earth?
Other than infrared light, what type of light is responsible for emitting visible radiation?
What type of light or laser will emit radiation concentrated mostly in the 8 to 25 um band?
What type of waves will char paper?

context: <b4_0>Infrared radiation<b4_0/> is popularly known as "<a0_0>heat radiation<a0_0/>"[citation needed], but light and <b7_0>electromagnetic waves<b7_0/> of any frequency will heat surfaces that absorb them. Infrared light from the Sun accounts for <a1_0>49%<a1_0/> of the heating of Earth, with the rest being caused by <a3_0>visible<a3_0/> light that is absorbed then re-radiated at longer wavelengths. <b6_0>Visible light or ultraviolet-emitting lasers<b6_0/> can char paper and incandescently hot objects emit visible radiation. Objects at room temperature will emit radiation concentrated mostly in the <a2_0>8 to 25<a2_0/> µm band, but this is not distinct from the emission of <b5_0>visible light<b5_0/> by incandescent objects and ultraviolet by even hotter objects (see black body and Wien's displacement law).
